content:
There are some major issues, almost 50% of the review questions in HTML have major bugs that make them unusable. Major bugs:
1)Review question text not populating correctly ‚Äî literally says BLANKBLANKBLANK
2)Review question answer fields not formatting correctly ‚Äî multiple copies of answer fields appear
3)Review question answer fields not populating correctly after pressing desired answer ‚Äî answers frequently do not populate the answer fields 
4)No lesson structure or save state ‚Äî every time you come to the app you are just getting random flash cards of information, there is no structured progression. Additionally, you cannot return to the same point, even in your practice set. If you close the app to look up information, you cannot return to the same problem to try to solve it
title: App does not work

content:
I have been on and off of Codecademy since the start of 2015. I have watched as the price of the course work goes up. Along with the increasingly improving coursework and resources the site provides. I would give the app a 5 star for those reasons. However I was very disappointed to load up the mobile app to find it does not have iPad support.

The app has that generic option of making the screen larger to fit the screen size. However it does not allow landscape mode which makes having a keyboard useless. 

I would love to see an iPad friendly version of this app so I can work on the go with a keyboard vs my thumbs on a phone.
title: This would be a 5 star if...

content:
In regards to the HTML review and practice:

The content repeats itself, in no particular order- there‚Äôs no progression or gradual knowledge building. You can‚Äôt see what you‚Äôre actually coding, and there seems to be many errors in the questions asked and the given answers to submit‚Ä¶ many more issues and annoyances like the seemingly random colors added into texts, but I digress. 

This is definitely not an app for you, if you‚Äôre a beginner, trying to learn the basics.
title: There are much better apps for learning

content: The app itself is a great learning tool to keep your mind sharp on subjects you already know, as far as trying to grasp new information it seems almost like reviewing flash cards. A. You learn something. But B. You see it over & over again. The material is very repetitive, i usually go under HTML & it‚Äôs nothing new nor difficult, if you can introduce more difficult problems or better questions. That would make it more challenging & engaging.
title: Concept is Good but.... The Material lacks.

content:
I‚Äôm very pleased with my Pro membership online, but this app is a disappointment. I thought it would be a teaching app, but actually it is only for review ‚Äî each session presents a few (five or so) random concepts, in no particular order, then quizzes you on them. 

There‚Äôs no back-catalogue or list of lessons to access, as I had expected. Which means you have no control over what concepts are being thrown at you in each session. Like I said, it‚Äôs completely random. 

So, if you already know your stuff, it‚Äôs a fun way to prove to yourself that you‚Äôve got skillz ‚Äî but if you‚Äôre trying to learn a new language or set of skills, you will quickly find yourself under water. 

I‚Äôm going back to my ‚Äòputer for learning JavaScript. There‚Äôs simply no way in this app to learn it (or anything else) from scratch. 

A disappointment, for sure. I expected better of you, CodecAcademy!
title: Not what I expected (buyer beware!)

content:
I‚Äôm a little disappointed with the way the app behaves on iPadOS. It seems this app is designed for the iPhone with the iPads features give an after thought. I‚Äôm not sure why it behaves as if there isn‚Äôt a landscape mode. Even when I place iPad in portrait position this app doesn‚Äôt use all of the real estate. Just frustrating and as mature this platform is there‚Äôs really no excuse. As it stands this app makes it harder to use. 

Please fix so we can work effectively.
title: Not bad but not truly an iPad app

content:
The website and the membership is well worth the costs. I absolutely using the web version of Codecademy. Why don‚Äôt you have an iPad friendly app utilizing the full screen capabilities  of the iPad for mobile learning, having it scale up and keeping it within the ratios of an iPhone is disappointing seeing as you even teach swift as a language. Please develop an iPad version of this app.

Thank you
title: Not iPad friendly

content: This is honestly so annoying! I want to access my own account in the app but you can‚Äôt because there‚Äôs no access to it! I am trying to sign up on the website using the same email I used for the app, but it‚Äôs making me a new account! I just want to have the same enrolled courses and progress that I have on the app!!! It‚Äôs irritating to have 2 different accounts on the website and app! BE BETTER PLEASE!!!!
title: PLEASE ADD ACCOUNT SETTINGS

content:
Although this comes up when I only filter iPad supported apps, this app is literally an iPhone app port that is oriented and sized for iPhone. They‚Äôve somehow justified that this is okay by adding a little button to expand it, which merely blows up all the pixels and feels like you‚Äôre working on an oversized, pixelated iPhone app. Which makes having it on the iPad pointless and insanely  misleading. Does this company know what the word ‚Äòethical‚Äô means? Doesn‚Äôt seem like it. 
Ugh
title: iPad app? Think again.

content:
I stopped using this years ago. Due to the format of it. It was pushing me through but I wasn‚Äôt learning due to lack of repetition. 

My girlfriend wanted to learn coding and wanted a good place to learn from. I just ruled this out.

1. The prices for pro went up. Have the site and app says I have pro and the other says I don‚Äôt.

2. The progress I had when doing this isn‚Äôt counted in %

3. The app login has issues.

4. The study material for the practice tests is bad. It‚Äôs by people trying to impress themselves or others. They‚Äôre not trying to teach.

The practice tests have nothing to do with the the practice material. And further more are written by... I don‚Äôt even know who the user is.
title: Issues on issues

content: Loving Codecademy pro; thank you Codecademy team for providing free access scholarships to students! This is making my social distancing fun and productive. I‚Äôve wanted to try out the data science path for a while... it‚Äôs an amazing learning tool!!!
title: Happy to be on board

content: I‚Äôve had to force close this app and restart it at least a half dozen times in the two days I‚Äôve been using it. Very buggy. The content in the python module is good so far, but the app itself makes the content useless because it won‚Äôt refresh, update progress, or even add a course when you select ‚Äústart this course.‚Äù
title: Ironically Buggy for an App that Teaches Coding

content: Very disappointed that the contents curation is quite different from website. I wish to access web codecademy contents - my career path lessons and exercises through mobile, but the mobile version is completely different. Maybe good for binge learners, but useless for aspiring coders who mostly work with desktop (laptop) web applications.
title: Does not sync with website

content: I‚Äôm in the process of switching careers from HVAC to Coding. And I‚Äôm sometimes really exhausted after work. So on my lunch breaks I‚Äôve been studying and practicing Codecademy. Awesome to have this hand held tool!

content: I‚Äôve been using this app to learn Python. Very impressive and easy to learn and use app. Highly recommended. Would say try this before its competitors.

content: If you really want to get the most use for your money I recommend this app!! Instead of scrolling through social media I‚Äôm learning this is a grea thing

When I launch the app, it gets to the login screen and the circular progress loops endless not allowing me to login. Never times out. The last bullet on your ‚ÄúFixed‚Äù list is NOT fixed.

Everyone doesn‚Äôt use Facebook or google. I should be able to just use my email that I have in order to use the app. Oh well.
title: No account

content: I was so excited to see there was an app available‚Ä¶and then so disappointed that the questions were basically unanswerable. I‚Äôll use CodeAcademy on my PC but I‚Äôm bummed I can‚Äôt use the app.

content: In case you do not feel compelled to sign up using your social media account letting you know now before install this app is not for you.

content: The app is very buggy.  The practice exams do not progress to next page after making all selections.  The Reviewed subjects do not match the practice exam questions.  Very disappointing.

content: No iPad support is a deal breaker for me. If the other reviews are to be believed, this is a great app otherwise. If you‚Äôre fine with using your phone, go for it.

title: iPad App? Nope, not really.

content: When entering in the suggested code I don‚Äôt see anything displayed. At this point I‚Äôm just guessing at the answers. Kinda sad I spent money on this.
title: Meh

content: What is the point in having an app, if I cannot work on any of courses that I am currently working on (on my laptop) while on my phone (in the app)? I logged into the app on my phone, and Code Foundations (Pro Skill Path), nor any of the other courses I am currently working on, are available to me. I cannot even search for them (nothing comes up when I do.) I paid to access the pro courses on the website, and none of the pro courses I am actively working on are accessible in the app. Very disappointing.
title: Abysmal App

content: It‚Äôs a great on the go solution for learning to code with bite sexed challenges
title: Just what I was looking for

content:
The platform is fantastic, the built in code editor takes the hassle out of setting up your dev environment in VScode/IDE while you‚Äôre just getting into programming. Their customer service is amazing as well. Any time I‚Äôve had an issue they reply quickly and straight to the point. I started using Codecademy to prepare for a software development boot camp and I have to say, I was over prepared thanks to Codecademy. Their catalogue contains a WEALTH of knowledge, regardless of what discipline of software development you‚Äôre in. I recommend Codecademy to every person I meet who‚Äôs interested in programming or wants to brush up on their skills in the latest tech.
(p.s. The Pro membership is 100% worth it)
title: Great platform, Great company

content: I joined the pro membership not too long ago and am disappointed with this app. I thought I could learn without prior coding knowledge but the app doesn‚Äôt teach, it just provides flash cards. It‚Äôs not useful to me as I have no background in the field. Since this holds no value and the app did not provide with it promised, I‚Äôm requesting a full refund please.
title: Does not teach code, just provides tips in flash card format

content: The app is pretty. Fluid animation.  nice‚Ä¶. The review material ok. Practice trash. Alot of the questions simply have bugs that make it impossible to input the right answer. They have community questions thrown in that are just plan wrong, and you cant remove them either in the settings. I have only tried the html course but i am so very disappointed. I will not even try the others. Plus it hasn‚Äôt been updated in 9 months. It seems like the developers has just given up on this app therefore it is not worth putting any money into. Please if you are a beginner, look elsewhere and don‚Äôt let this app confuse you. Maybe the desktop website is better because i heard good things about how it is comparable to free code camp. Anyway please don‚Äôt waste a second on the app though.
title: Bugs and QuestionsMistakes in Practice

content: I used to be able to code back in my MySpace days üòâ but this just shows me how little I know about the behind the scenes in coding. I just started and I‚Äôm so excited to dive in. The app makes it super easy and I‚Äôm thrilled I get the chance to take this challenge on.
title: Awesome

content: This app is still great for learning. I‚Äôve just had issues picking up where I left off on my computer. The format of the app and its content aren‚Äôt the same as he website so it‚Äôs somewhat confusing.The version of code academy you use on your computer is also better organized so you understand how far you are progressing through the lesson and you are limited on the phone to a certain extent because you can‚Äôt type as naturally as you would on a keyboard. It still is made very well though and I‚Äôm saying all these things constructively, Codecademy is the bomb ! I love what you guys are doing for people ! ü•≥üòÅüëçü•á
title: Wonderful app when in a pinch

content: It was hard for me to learn/practice syntax when I don‚Äôt have access to my computer. When I heard about this feature, I was interested in trying it out. It turns out the interface here is really cool and helpful. The daily review is a great, quick refresher, and the fill-in-the-blanks practice is mobile-friendly and clever. This is a great supplement, but of course, it won‚Äôt replace you typing code on your computer. I use this app virtually every day.
title: More helpful than I anticipated

content:
I‚Äôve used several different coding applications and the setup of this one is the most strange to me. Why does the content in the lessons keep changing when you leave and come back? Why does the resume button at the top of the page not actually resume your progress in the course but take you to a testing ground? Why don‚Äôt they begin the programming languages at the beginning with the fundamentals? I kept feeling like i was missing out on content because i knew the lesson material changes and i was introduced to several new concepts (which is actually great because I‚Äôm still learning) but wasn‚Äôt taught to the point where i would be able to duplicate the results of the teacher, give a comprehensive understanding of what i was being shown, or felt like i could actually explain what i had learned. Why not have all the material you want to include in the lessons already there so you don‚Äôt have people swipe through five slides and then come back realizing there‚Äôs entirely new content? If i learn a new language i want to learn it well. 
I‚Äôm not an advanced programmer yet so there‚Äôs a lot of things i still don‚Äôt know, and the lessons introduced a page of code, and proceeded to explain one element. I need to know all the details in the beginning, like what this term means, and what this does, and five slides later I didn‚Äôt feel like i was ready to be tested on anything because i missed so much of what was going on.
title: Confusing layout

content: Just signed up for the pro and figured I could use the app to learn. Could not even get passed the notification part when trying to resume. I hit continue and just get a white screen. Kinda disappointing that a learning to code app don‚Äôt work.... wonder what that says about the organization.
title: Not working

content: It‚Äôs definitely a challenge for a beginner with zero experience but I enjoyed learning concepts and testing them out. All while repeating the problems until you get it right. I look forward to learning more so it can all slow down and become more clear in translation and structure. 5 stars for this app and program!
title: Code academy app

content:
Very useful app. 4 stars because on phone, we want to be able to hold our phone horizontal instead of vertical so the code and run longer without so many line breaks. 

The icon shown when it‚Äôs time to practice shows someone holding their phone sideways and yet we can only hold our phone vertically. 

Fixing this would make it 5 stars
title: Vertical is distracting

Like you could go into setting and change the keyboard for just Codecademy and put in like the <> easier to get to or something.
title: Doesn‚Äôt have the typing of the code just studying!
